interlinear-text.item: Forbes Persian stories translated to Wakhi

phrase.item: A person asked Plato "In the many years you were travelling at sea by ship, what wonders did you see at sea?"
Said he, "The wonder that I saw was that I arrived safely on shore from the sea."
A beggar went to the door of a rich man and asked for one thing.
From inside the house came the answer that the wife is not at home.
The beggar said: "I asked for a piece of bread, it's not a wife I asked for, that I should get such an answer."
There was a doctor who, whenever he would go to the graveyard, used to wrap his scarf around his head and face. People asked him: "What's the reason for that?"
He said: I'm ashamed before the people in this graveyard because they have died from my medicine.
One day a king went hunting with his son.
Unclear what məʃ means here.
The weather was hot.
The king and his son put his cloak on a jester's back.
The king smiled and said: "Oh jester, there's a donkey's load on you."
Unexplained form: apkɨmɨt
The jester said: "Maybe two donkey's loads"
They said to a hunchback: "Do you wish your back were straight or other people's backs were hunched like yours?"
Said he: "I wish that other people's backs might become crooked, so that we might look one another in the eye."
One day a king was upset with the poet, he ordered the executioner: "Kill (him) in my presence!"
The executioner went to fetch the sword.
The poet said to the people present: "Until the sword is fetched, strike me so that the king is happy."
The king smiled and forgave his fault.
A person obtained great dignity.
A friend came to congratulate him.
The person asked: "What have you come for?"
The friend became ashamed.
Said he: "Dost thou not know me?"
It is I, thine old friend. I came before you in order to weep; for I heard that thou hast become blind.
A person ran off with a beggar's turban, the beggar went and sat in the graveyard.
People said to him: "Seeing as the man took thy turban towards the garden, wherefore hast thou sat down in the graveyard?"
: Said he: "He will come here in the end."
That's why I have sat down here.
A picture-maker went to a city. There he began to make medicine.
Some days later a person from his homeland arrived in town.
Seeing him, he asked: "What work dost thou do now?"
Said he: "I make medicine."
Asked the man: "What for?"
Said he: "Because if I err in this work, it is buried in the earth."
King Alexander, Lord of Two Horns, one day passed by a beggar.
Said he: "O beggar, what wishest thou from me?"
Said the beggar: The flies trouble me, order them to trouble me not.
Said the king: "Ask of me something which I have the power to do"
Said the beggar: "If you cannot command a (mere) fly, what shall I ask of thee?"
One day a person said to himself that whatever there is on earth or in heaven might be all for my sake. God created such great (things) for me.
Then a fly perched on his nose.
Said the fly: Does such aggrandisement suit you?
For that reason, God made all in heaven and on earth for thee, but made thee for my sake.
Seest thou not that thou art greater than I?
A person praised a merchant.
He received nothing.
Thereupon he slandered (him).
Two days later the person went and sat before his gate.
Said the merchant: "O person!
Thou madest praise, I gave thee nothing. Thou madest slander, I said nothing: Now wherefore sittest thou here?"
Said he: "Now I hope that should you die I may sing thy lament."
